bibl.title: Letter from John J. Moran to Philip Showalter Hench, October 5, 1940

div1.p: Moran informs Hench that he has been exploring the area where Camp Lazear was located and has seen part of the infected-clothing building and the site of the mosquito building.

div1.head: Letter from John J. Moran to Philip Showalter Hench, October 5, 1940
div1.opener:
VIA AIR MAIL
Havana, Oct. 5, 1940.
Dr. Philip S. Hench,
MAYO CLINIC,
Rochester, Minn.
Dear Doctor:
div1.p:
Sorry I could not make good my promise to send you airmail
particulars by yesterday's mail. Just as I sent the messenger to
catch the air mail, at 1:00 P. M., on the 3rd, it began to rain cats and dogs
and it rained steadily into the night. Miss Rojas telephoned me to put it
off until yesterday morning, since the matter she had to discuss with me
would involve Zunzunegui (pronounced Zoon-zoon-eggy), the chap we talked
to and who was seven years old at the time of the experiments. Yesterday
morning, I went to see Miss Rojas. She showed be book entries, written
by her father, proving that the camp site was not ceded gratis but that
a rental of $20.00 American Gold, per month, had been paid from and inclu-
November 9th, 1900 to October 10th, 1901, Buildings No. 1 and No. 2, re-
maining the property of the owner. All this time and prior to leasing
of the camp site, the property belonged to Dr. Rojas but it was rented to
a tenant named Sosa and the rental was split 50-50 between owner and
tenant, checks being handed to Dr. Rojas, who was evidently one of the
two parties to the contract of lease. Entries in his Journal-Cash Book
are made regularly, the first check having been received from “Major Mr.
Read” and subsequent checks from Major J. R. Kean, the latter evidently
acting as Disbursing Quartermaster. It must be remembered that the fund
for all expenses connected with the experimental camp was a special one,
hence a Medical Corps officer, in this case Major Kean, acted as Disbursing
Officer, evidently. The plot involved for the camp site was to consist
of four to six acres. Miss Rojas is having all entries copied VERBATIM
and will take them to Mrs. Phillips for translation. Sra. Rojas and my-
self will certify to the translated entries, when and as they are prepared
and ready to forward to you. When I got through with Miss Rojas, I
went over to look for Zunzunegui who now owns the limestone quarry and
limekilns which you saw on the way over to the far end of the quarry
from which you took the picture. He was not at home but Mrs. Z. told me
that he would be home for lunch around 12:00. He did not show up, so I
left his house at 12:30, leaving my phone number. I was not able to get
in touch with him, after a half dozen calls, until near 8:00 P. M. He
then told me that, today being Saturday, he had to make his Saturday
collections for lime delivered during the week. I suggested that he
might be able to see me between 7:30 and 8:00 A. M. this morning, to which
he agreed. I have just come from his place. Results: The oldest of
the shacks (the one on the extreme right, facing from the road) is in
part Bldg. No. 1 (Infecteed Clothing) and I found the tongued and grooved
boards on the inside, weather boarding on the outside. The mosquito
building was torn down and used for kindling wood about four or five years
ago. Slabs of the concrete floor can still be seen in the tilled field
where you had some photos of me taken, the site being much more to the
left, viewed from the front of Bldg. No. 1, than where I stand in the
picture. I wandered all over the place yesterday and discovered indeter-
minable “something” appearing on the right, shown in the Army photo,
your number 17-b, also the concrete affair, which served as a small
reservoir, shown near Bldg. No. 2 on the extreme left of your photo No.
16-a (Army Medical Museum No. 40731) If I can get hold of the photograph-
er, I will go out there this afternoon and endeavor to reconstruct the
Dr. Philip S. Hench.
-- 2 --
Oct. 5, 1940.
whole picture as per that general view. We will try and work out the
point from which it was taken and then show where the Poplar “Alamo”
tree was that sticks out like a sore thumb in that picture. It was cut
down and uprooted by Z's father, years ago, but he showed me where it was.
The “concrete affair”, which could not figure for anything in particular,
was built by slaves and it was the starting point for the first limestone
excavated and the first limekiln built on the farm. Around it, a very
extensive tract has been honeycombed and today Z. has three trucks haul-
ing slaked lime to Havana and other points around Havana. The small
reservoir was undoubtedly used for water for slaking the lime and maybe
for other purposes. There was no activity whatever there when Camp
Lazear was built. Z's father was the first to develop the business on
a large scale and his contract, I think, is dated 1905. The quarry which
leads to the brick plant was an entirely separate affair. Dr. Rojas was
interested in that business with a partner. Z., however, went into the
lime business exclusively for himself.

The roots of the poplar tree back of the No. 1 building come
clear under the building but its limbs have never been allowed to grow
high enough to reach much higher than the roof of the shack. It is one of
the small trees back of Building No. 1 shown in your 16-a, Medical Museum
No. 40731, so thinks Zunzunegui and he may be right. He also thinks the
Framboyan tree, with which you are familiar, was in its infancy at that
time for it has been there as long as he can remember. You may be entirely
sure that none of the buildings in the Army Medical Museum photo belonged
to the Rojas family.

By the way, I have three sections of the limb indicated by
you to the old lady tenant of the shack and I want to know if you want
me to arrange to have them sent up or try to take them with me. Please
let me know about this by return mail.

It is about mail time, so will close for the present. A lot
of the pictures we took will be of no service whatsoever, but I trust
those to be taken today will be.
